thread.title: Jeremy Corbyn and the Brexiteers should take a bow as they've made politics interesting again
thread.title_full: Jeremy Corbyn and the Brexiteers should take a bow as they've made politics interesting again

author: Mike Kelly
title: Jeremy Corbyn and the Brexiteers should take a bow as they've made politics interesting again
text:
Jeremy Corbyn and the Brexiteers should take a bow as they've made politics interesting again 08:30, 17 Jul 2016 Reports about the 'decline of British politics' can't be more wrong as it's not been this interesting for years Shares Comments Get daily news by email David Cameron leaves Downing Street for the last time as Prime Minister with his wife Samantha Cameron and children Nancy Cameron, Arthur Cameron and Florence Cameron 
There was an article last week titled the ‘rise of Theresa May and the decline of British politics’. 
The rise of Theresa May fine, but I was taken aback by the suggestion of a slump in politics as, frankly, it hasn’t been this interesting for years. 
And the Labour party and the foibles of its traditional supporters, particularly up here, can take much of the credit for it. 
First it gave us Jeremy Corbyn as leader to free up the inner radical of those who think austerity is not a policy but a punishment. 
Then came the EU referendum . With Prime Minister David Cameron and Chancellor George Osborne’s delicates on the block if the country voted Brexit, the Labour heartlands, including the North East, voted Leave even though judged rationally, Remain was the better option for them. But taking down your tormentors was just too good a chance to pass up. Lauren Hurley/PA Wire George Osborne resigned from Government as Theresa May begun her Cabinet reshuffle 
No matter what you think of Corbyn or the Brexiteers, what would politics be without them? Pretty dull, I’d say. 
If Corbyn’s leadership challenge hadn’t succeeded last September we’d have had a Labour party barely distinguishable from the Tory government. 
An exaggeration you think? Well, after Ed Miliband stood down Harriet Harman became temporary leader until a new one was elected. 
She decided last July Labour should abstain - ie not vote - against the government’s welfare bill which included restrictions on in-work benefits, including curbs on child and working tax credits, part of £12bn worth of cuts sought by ministers by 2020. 
Harman took the decision because she thought it would play better with the public - standing up for those at the sharp end of society seemed to come second in her thinking. 
This is the same Harman who is in charge of Angela Eagle’s campaign to replace Corbyn. Corbyn voted against the government’s welfare bill, Eagle abstained. 
One thing we learned last week was if Corbyn really is the problem, Eagle definitely isn’t the answer. Former Shadow Cabinet Minister Angela Eagle launches her bid for the Labour leadership 
What does she stand for? Her laughably bad campaign launch looked like she was flogging a perfume called ‘Angela’ rather than an alternative political view. 
And as for her excruciating: ‘BBC! Robert Peston!! Cooee!!!’ - it was a political tumbleweed moment she’ll never live down. 
Meanwhile Brexit has done for the Chuckle brothers, Cameron and Osborne. For the life of me I still don’t know what Cameron stands for either, other than winning at all costs. Read More 
As for Osborne, he tweeted: “Others will judge - I hope I’ve left the economy in a better state than I found it.” 
They have and he hasn’t. 
On Thursday a poll came out revealing crisis-ridden Labour was just one point behind the Tories, 35 to 36. Game on and I can’t wait for the next round.
